channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Criticism, and Rare Words of Support, as China Watches Taiwan Protests
item.description: Hu Jia, a dissident who is under house arrest in Beijing, said he supported the demonstrators in Taipei and urged mainland Chinese students to emulate them.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Student protesters have been occupying Taiwan's legislature for more than a week.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Family Fights for Body of Activist Who Died in Detention
item.description: Two weeks after her death in custody, the government has yet to release Cao Shunli’s body to her family, and a lawyer describes “harassment” to drop the case.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Facing Rising Seas, Bangladesh Confronts the Consequences of Climate Change
item.description: Though countries like Bangladesh have contributed little to the industrial pollution driving climate change, they will suffer the most from the devastating consequences.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:credit: Kadir van Lohuizen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bangladesh, with its low elevation and severe tropical storms, is among the countries most vulnerable to the effects of climate change, though it has contributed little to the emissions that are driving it.

item.title: Search for Missing Jet Is Moved Nearly 700 Miles, Based on Radar Analysis
item.description: The revision of the search area, based on further analysis by an international team working with Malaysian officials, means that Australia is redirecting the search far from the floating objects seen in the previous search area.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT, THOMAS FULLER and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Envoy Describes Crisis in Anbar
item.description: The United Nations envoy to Iraq said Thursday that about 400,000 people had been displaced this year by violence in Anbar Province, and the United Nations Security Council expressed “grave concern” about recent events there.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Condemns North Korean Test
item.description: The United Nations Security Council unanimously condemned North Korea on Thursday for launching two midrange missiles a day earlier, with Pyongyang’s main ally, China, joining in the criticism.

item.title: Zbigniew Romaszewski, Physicist Who Resisted Poland’s Communists, Dies at 74
item.description: He played an early role in a seminal workers’ rights group founded in the 1970s, which helped establish the Solidarity movement.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Zbigniew Romaszewski, center, and his wife Irena Zofia , in a Polish military court in Warsaw. The couple and seven other defendants were convicted of spreading false information and conducting illegal union activity by their work with an underground radio station.

item.title: Search for Lost Jet Is Complicated by Geopolitics and Rivalries
item.description: While the United States, China and others have collaborated in the search for the Malaysian plane, each in its own way has been hesitant to reveal the extent of its surveillance abilities.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A relative of passengers on the missing Malaysia Airlines flight spoke to members of the news media on Wednesday at a hotel in Beijing.

item.title: Serra Da Capivara National Park Journal: Discoveries Challenge Beliefs on Humans’ Arrival in the Americas
item.description: Archaeologists say humans reached what is now northeast Brazil as early as 22,000 years ago, upending a prevailing belief of 20th-century archaeology in the United States that people arrived in the Americas about 13,000 years ago.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Soul-Searching as Japan Ends a Man’s Decades on Death Row
item.description: It took the courts nearly half a century to conclude that the evidence against him was likely fabricated by police investigators and to order the retrial he sought.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Iwao Hakamada, 78, who has been on death row in Japan for 45 years, was released from a Tokyo prison on Thursday.

item.title: Obama Seeks to Calm Saudis as Paths Split
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s leaders are feeling increasingly compelled to go their own way in dealing with Iran, Syria, Egypt and the Muslim Brotherhood.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: A Muslim Brotherhood supporter threw a canister of tear gas in Cairo this week.

item.title: Qatar Finds U.S. Couple Guilty in Daughter’s Death
item.description: An American couple accused of killing their adopted daughter by depriving her of sustenance were unexpectedly found guilty and sentenced to three years in prison.
item.dc:creator: By SHABINA S. KHATRI and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Pakistani Gets Death Penalty for Blasphemy
item.description: A case that set off rioting last year in a Christian neighborhood is now likely to put a spotlight on capital punishment in Pakistan, which has never carried out an execution under its blasphemy laws.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI and SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: U.S. Investigates Brothers From Ecuador With Ties to Campaigns
item.description: The fugitives have been investigated to determine whether any of the millions the men were accused of pilfering in their home country made it to the United States.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: World Briefing: The Philippines: Peace Accord Is Signed
item.description: The Philippine government signed a peace accord with the country’s largest Muslim rebel group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front, on Thursday, the culmination of years of negotiations.

item.title: World Briefing: South Korea: North Korean Boat Seized
item.description: South Korea’s military seized a North Korean fishing boat on Thursday that it said had crossed a disputed maritime border after ignoring warnings to retreat.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: France: Actress Wins Privacy Case
item.description: A French court has ordered Closer magazine to pay 15,000 euros, about $20,700, to an actress for publishing photographs of what it said showed President François Hollande visiting her for a tryst.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Former Prime Minister Announces Candidacy for President of Ukraine
item.description: Yulia V. Tymoshenko, the polarizing former prime minister, has long harbored presidential ambitions and will be the most widely known contender in the election.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK REEVELL and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Yulia V. Tymoshenko said she would run for president in elections to be held in May.

item.title: World Briefing: Human Rights Panel Criticizes U.S.
item.description: A United Nations human rights panel has called for more oversight and transparency in the program of targeted drone strikes carried out by the United States.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Alstom of France Cooperating in U.S. Bribery Inquiry
item.description: Discussions are said to be continuing between the company, an industrial conglomerate and the Justice Department over a possible fine.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Bombs Kill at Least 33 in Baghdad
item.description: A series of bombings in Baghdad killed at least 33 people and wounded dozens more on Thursday, Iraqi officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: President Obama Meets With Pope Francis
item.description: President Obama and Pope Francis on Thursday skirted social issues that have generated tension between some Roman Catholic leaders and the president.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: President Obama with Pope Francis on Thursday at the Vatican.

item.title: Congress Approves Aid of $1 Billion for Ukraine
item.description: The measure passed after the White House dropped efforts to tie it to an overhaul of the International Monetary Fund negotiated by President Obama.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN and DAVID S. JOACHIM

item.title: Recordings, Posted Online, Rattle Officials in Turkey
item.description: A recording was posted on YouTube in which officials were heard discussing a plot to establish a justification for military strikes in Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: Russian Businessman’s Death Remains Mystery, Coroner Says
item.description: A British coroner said Thursday that he could not say whether Boris A. Berezovsky, a businessman and power broker, died of suicide or homicide.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
